title.narrative: Response to Dominican Republic Deportation of Haitians through Haitian Red Cross

description.narrative:
In 2013, the Constitutional Court of the Dominican Republic issued the Judgment "TC 168/13" resulting in withdrawal of nationality from a population estimated at 400,000 people, including 300,000 of Haitian origin. On 22 May 2014 the Dominican Congress passed legislation establishing a registration procedure and regularization of persons of foreign origin born in the Dominican Republic between 1929 and 2007 or "Ley de Régimen Especial y Naturalización 169-14." This law established two distinct groups:
- Group A: consisting of 24,000 heads of families with members of their families (a total estimated 100,000 people) were born in the Dominican Republic and registered at the civil registry office;
- Group B: 55,000 heads of families with members of their families (200,000 people) were born in the Dominican Republic and have not been registered at the civil registry office.
The Haitian Red Cross will support the displaced people with water and sanitation services, including 4 bladders, 1 de-sludging truck, 1 tanker for the distribution of safe water, and 2 latrines for women and men.
It will offer first aid through a medical center with nurses and volunteers, with 2 ambulances and personnel trained in first aid. Relief items will be made available, and volunteers will be trained in relief distribution and Open Data Kit (ODK) plus Mega V in order to realize the distribution of NFIs like Hygiene kits, baby kits, and more.
Restoring Families Links services are provided, allowing the tracing department to provide free 3-minute calls to the newly arrived migrants as part of its RFL services.
Transportation for the Displaced Persons will be made available. The HRC will provide transportation through 4 buses with 18 seats for the displaced people leaving from the six points in the border to the Governmental Centers. The transportation will be offer three times a day on a specific schedule.
